verseObjects.text: In what direction has your beloved gone,
so that we may seek him with you?
My beloved has gone down to his garden,
to graze in the garden and to gather lilies.
I am my beloved's, and my beloved is mine;
he grazes among the lilies with pleasure.
The man speaking to the woman
You are as beautiful as Tirzah, my love,
as awe-inspiring as an army with its banners.
Turn your eyes away from me,
Your hair is like a flock of goats
going down from the slopes of Gilead.
Your teeth are like a flock of ewes
coming up from the washing place.
and none among them is bereaved.
Your cheeks are like pomegranate halves
There are sixty queens, eighty concubines,
My dove, my undefiled, is the only one;
she is the only daughter of her mother;
she is the favorite one of the woman who bore her.
The young women saw her and called her blessed;
the queens and the concubines saw her also, and they praised her:
What the queens and the concubines said
"Who is this who appears like the dawn,
as awe-inspiring as an army with its banners?"
I went down into the grove of nut trees
to see the young growth in the valley,
to see whether the vines had budded,
and whether the pomegranates were in bloom.
I was so happy that I felt
I was riding in the chariot of a prince.
The friends speaking to the woman
Turn back, turn back, you perfect woman;

verseObjects.content: + \ft Some versions read, \fqa you woman from Shulam \fqa* .

verseObjects.text: turn back, turn back so that we may gaze on you.
The woman speaking to the friends
Why do you gaze on the perfect woman,

verseObjects.content: + \ft Some versions read, \fqa on the woman from Shulam \fqa* .

verseObjects.text: as if on the dance between two armies?

verseObjects.content: + \ft Some versions read, \fqa on the dance of Mahanaim \fqa* .

verseObjects.text: The women of Jerusalem speaking to the young woman
